Notes: A craving or desire considered a root of suffering in Theravada Buddhism.
An intense dislike or aversion, one of the three poisons causing suffering.
Confusion or misunderstanding of reality, leading to suffering.
A pleasant feeling arising from wholesome causes.
An unpleasant feeling associated with loss or suffering.
A neutral state of mind characterized by calmness and balance.
Clinging to objects or ideas, leading to suffering.
Repulsion or avoidance of unpleasant experiences.
Lack of knowledge or awareness, leading to delusion.
A feeling of empathy and desire to alleviate others' suffering.
Confidence or trust in the Buddha's teachings.
Expectation of positive outcomes based on wholesome causes.
An unpleasant emotion caused by anticipation of danger.
Resentment towards others' success or possessions.
A painful feeling arising from perceived wrongdoing.
A state of peacefulness and calm.
Lack of strong feeling either way.
Feelings of pity and sorrow for others.
Fear of losing something valuable to another.
Letting go of resentment towards others.
Desire to learn or know more.
Feeling of being upset due to obstacles.
Quality of being friendly and considerate.
Disinterest due to lack of stimulation.
A deep-seated longing or thirst, considered a root of suffering in Theravada Buddhism.
